texts.shortText: Clinus superciliosus (part) - this is one of several recently described species within the C. superciliosus complex, thus any biological information (on diet, reproduction, etc) published prior to 2012 refers to the whole group and not to any one of the six component species now recognized.

Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are smallish, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2-3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This species has 38 spines and 8 rays in the dorsal fin, of which the first 3 spines are raised into a tall crest, but with only a shallow notch between the 3rd and 4th spines. First 6 spines also have a small filament at their tip. Cirrus above eye a small, narrow stalk ending in a few thin, tapering branches.

Colour primarily formed of about 5 longitudinal brown or green broken stripes consisting of alternating light and dark blocks. Head above middle of eye dark with radiating broken stripes, but below eye head characteristically pale yellow or white with a diagonal darker stripe.
The single measured specimen reported was 13 cm total length, but this cannot be taken as a maximum length, which can only be established once more specimens are measured.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Betty’s Bay.

Very little is known about this species and the original description and later published accounts are based on just a single specimen captured at Betty’s bay (hence the species name, which refers to the exasperation of the researchers in being unable to find more specimens!)

Recently found to be fairly common in False Bay but shy and difficult to photograph.
Unknown for this species but other similar clinids feed on a variety of small invertebrates, mainly crustaceans, molluscs and polychaetes.

(as assessed for ‘C. superciliosus’ before splitting species) Females reach sexual maturity between about 110-120 mm and males between 50-60 mm, although males eventually grow much larger than females and there appears to be a dominance hierarchy based on male size (so large males probably monopolise females). Between 20-144 live young are born per brood at an average length of 20 mm.

One of several closely-related species in the C. superciliosus complex, but recognised by the combination of tall crest on dorsal fin, small slender cirrus above eye and colour pattern, particularly the pale lower section of head.

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 5 (p. 393).

Holleman, W, Von Der Heyden, S & Zsilavecz, G (2012). Delineating the fishes of the Clinus superciliosus species complex in southern African waters (Blennioidei: Clinidae: Clinini), with the validation of Clinus arborescens Gilchrist & Thompson, 1908 and Clinus ornatus Gilchrist & Thompson, 1908, and with descriptions of two new species. Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, 166(4), 827-853.
